name: Jodhpur
fun_fact: Fun fact: Shri Mishrilal Hotel has been serving Makhaniya Lassi since 1927â€”nearly a century of the same creamy, saffron-infused yogurt drink topped with a thick layer of malai (cream) that locals line up for daily, making it Jodhpur's most Instagram-famous breakfast.

hero_dishes.name: Makhaniya Lassi at Shri Mishrilal Hotel
hero_dishes.description: Insanely thick and creamy yogurt drink flavored with saffron, cardamom, and rose water, topped with a huge scoop of malai (clotted cream)â€”rich enough to be dessert
hero_dishes.origin_story: Established in 1927, Shri Mishrilal Hotel near the Southern Gate has been serving this legendary lassi for nearly 100 years. The thickness comes from hanging yogurt in cloth to drain all liquid, creating something closer to mousse than drink
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Shri Mishrilal Hotel (near Southern Gateâ€”since 1927, the most famous spot)

hero_dishes.name: Mirchi Bada at Choudhary Namkeen
hero_dishes.description: Large green chili stuffed with spiced potato filling, dipped in gram flour batter, and deep-fried until golden and crispyâ€”spicy, crunchy, addictive
hero_dishes.origin_story: Choudhary Namkeen in Sardarpura is legendary for making the tastiest mirchi bada in Jodhpur. The chili is stuffed with potato or cauliflower, creating a spicy-savory explosion that's Jodhpur's favorite snack
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Choudhary Namkeen (Sardarpura), Surya Namkeen (smoked version), Mishrilal Hotel, or Shahi Samosa

hero_dishes.name: Pyaaz Kachori
hero_dishes.description: Crispy fried pastry stuffed with spiced onion fillingâ€”crunchy outside, flavorful inside, served with tangy chutneys
hero_dishes.origin_story: Jodhpur's kachoris are famous across Rajasthan. The onion version is local pride. Street vendors make them fresh throughout the day, served piping hot with green chutney
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Shandar Sweet Home, Janta Sweet Home, Arora Chat Bhandar, or Clock Tower Road street vendors

hero_dishes.name: Mawa Kachori
hero_dishes.description: Sweet kachori stuffed with dried fruits, nuts, and thickened milk (mawa), fried and dipped in sugar syrupâ€”crispy, sweet, decadent
hero_dishes.origin_story: This sweet version of kachori is Jodhpur's dessert specialty. The mawa (reduced milk) filling with nuts creates a rich, indulgent treat that pairs perfectly with the savory mirchi bada and lassi
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Janta Sweet Home, Shandar Sweet Home, or sweets shops near Clock Tower

signature_drinks.name: Makhaniya Lassi
signature_drinks.description: Thick, creamy saffron-cardamom yogurt drink topped with malaiâ€”Jodhpur's signature beverage
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served in clay cups or glasses, eaten with a spoon because it's too thick to drink. Locals pair it with spicy mirchi badaâ€”the cooling lassi balances the heat. Essential breakfast or afternoon snack

signature_drinks.name: Masala Chai
signature_drinks.description: Strong spiced tea with milk, cardamom, ginger, and lots of sugarâ€”the fuel of Rajasthan
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served boiling hot in small glasses or clay cups. Drunk throughout the day at street stalls. The sugar and spices provide energy in the desert heat

food_culture_notes: Makhaniya lassi is so thick you need a spoonâ€”it's more like eating yogurt mousse than drinking
Mirchi bada paired with makhaniya lassi is the ultimate Jodhpur combination: spicy heat followed by creamy coolness
Clock Tower Road is the street food epicenterâ€”everything from kachoris to mirchi bada to lassi
Winter is the best time for mirchi badaâ€”locals eat these spicy fritters at every winter gathering
